verses.text: Blessed is the man who does not walk in the counsel of the wicked, nor stand in the way of sinners, nor sit in the seat of scoffers;
verses.comment: The word 'blessed' in Hebrew ('ashrei') implies ongoing happiness rooted in right relationship with God, not mere outward prosperity. Note how the progression of walking, standing, and sitting shows an increasing association with sin. The verse teaches that happiness comes from refusing sinful influences and instead seeking God's wisdom and company. Early Church writers saw in this a foreshadowing of the truly righteous man, Jesus Christ, who kept perfectly free from sin and associated with sinners only to redeem them. Christians are called not only to avoid sin but also to choose the company of the faithful.

verses.text: but his delight is in the law of the LORD, and on his law he meditates day and night.
verses.comment: Here, 'law' means the teaching or instruction of the LORD (Hebrew: Torah). Delighting in the law refers to an attitude of love and obedience towards God's commands, meditating means pondering and internalizing them. New Testament believers see in this the call to live by every word of God (cf. Matt. 4:4). The tradition of meditating on Scripture throughout the day foreshadows practices such as lectio divina. The verse highlights the need for continual engagement with God's Word, not occasional or purely intellectual reading, for true spiritual fruitfulness.

verses.text: He is like a tree planted by streams of water, which yields its fruit in season, and whose leaf does not wither. In all that he does, he prospers.
verses.comment: The image of the tree by streams of water symbolizes the stable, nourished life of the righteous. The spiritual interpretation sees the streams as the life-giving grace of God found in the sacraments and continual prayer. Fruitfulness 'in season' suggests a life marked not by constant outward success, but by growth and good works at God’s appointed times (cf. Gal. 5:22-23). The prosperity here is spiritual, not merely material. The withered leaf contrasts with the fate of the wicked, and reminds the reader of the call to perseverance in faith.

verses.text: The wicked are not so, but are like chaff that the wind drives away.
verses.comment: Chaff is the useless husk separated from grain at harvest, easily blown away by the wind. This vivid contrast points to the instability and ultimate judgment of the ungodly. When Jesus speaks of separating wheat from chaff (Matt. 3:12), he echoes this psalm. The absence of deep roots or connection to the source of life highlights the necessity of belonging to the community of the faithful, partaking in their shared spiritual sustenance.

verses.text: Therefore, the wicked will not stand in the judgment, nor sinners in the assembly of the righteous.
verses.comment: The 'judgment' here refers both to God's temporal judgments and the final, eschatological judgment. The 'assembly of the righteous' points to the gathered people of God—later seen as the visible, united Church. Only those living according to God's will are able to remain in that assembly. This reflects the importance of being gathered into the communion of the faithful as part of salvation, not merely as isolated individuals.

verses.text: For the LORD knows the way of the righteous, but the way of the wicked will perish.
verses.comment: To 'know' in Hebrew carries the sense of loving knowledge, approval, and watchful care. God guides and preserves the righteous, while the wicked end up in destruction. The double path reflects Jesus' later teaching on the narrow and broad way (Matt. 7:13-14). The psalm, beginning with 'blessed' and ending with the fate of the wicked, gives a foundational vision of the two ways open to every soul: one within the gathered people of God, nourished and fruitful; the other apart from God's blessing, leading to loss. Christ is seen as the truly righteous man and the true way (John 14:6) that leads to life.
